Summary: Fine example of a typical Mendip gorge for walking, caving and climbing
Description 1: Burrington Combe is a Carboniferous Limestone gorge near the village of Burrington on the north side of the Mendip Hills Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty in North Somerset England. Combe or Coombe is a word of Celtic origin found in several forms on all of the British Isles denoting a steep sided valley or hollow. Burrington Combe is a gorge though the limestone hills although there is now no river running through it. Various cave entrances are exposed which have been occupied by humans for over 1000 years with a hillfort being built beside the combe in the Iron Age. The geology has led to a diversity of plant life. According to legend Augustus Montague Toplady was inspired to write the hymn Rock of Ages while sheltering under a rock in the combe although recent scholars have disputed this claim.

Summary: Amateur dramatics society in  Weston super Mare in Somerset, which has been running for over 60 years.
Description 1: We are an amateur dramatics society with members from many different backgrounds. We put on several shows every year, mainly at the Theatre in the Hut which is owned by the Wayfarers. Members do not get paid for the shows we put on, as all proceeds from ticket sales (after payment of royalties and licenses etc) go towards the upkeep and improvement of the theatre. What we do get is a tremendous amount of satisfaction and a great social life.
Tags: Weston, theatre, plays

Summary: Vineyard and Conference/Wedding venue
Description 1: Aldwick Estate, set in the Mendip countryside, is home to Somersets largest vineyard, producing award winning wines. Pre booked Tour & Tastings offer a guided tour of the vineyards and tasting of Aldwick wines. Aldwick Estate is set in the heart of North Somerset between Blagdon Lake and the A38, 4 miles south of Bristol Airport and 10 miles south of Bristol City Centre, overlooked by the beautiful Mendip Hills Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty.   Aldwick sits on 300 acres of working farm, in the same family for 5 generations, with just over 11 acres of vineyard and an award winning wedding & events venue that can host up to 200 guests.    Since their first release, wine production has grown year on year, with bottles being sold through the venue, online, in local stores, and with selected traders across the UK. Aldwick Wines have not only achieved national recognition but also won international awards for its still & sparkling wines.  For information on Tour & Tastings, please visit http://aldwickcourtfarm.co.uk or call the team who will be happy to help further
Tags: drink, wine, events, wedding venues, wine tasting, vineyard, tours, mendip hills
Opening_Times: Cellar Door Sales Mon-Thurs 10am -5pm.  Vineyard Tour & Tastings - Pre-booking only

Summary: The Tropicana on Weston super Mare seafront offers facilities for live music, theatre, exhibitions and private hire functions.
Description 1: The Tropicana Weston super Mare is a 1930s Art Deco building located on the thriving promenade. Following the world wide phenomena of Banksys Dismaland in 2015, the former seafront swimming pool has received a light refurbishment and now offers facilities for live music, theatre, exhibitions and private hire functions.  In addition to a comprehensive in house programme of music and theatre, the venue is also available for private hire and we want to make sure that your booking, whatever the size, runs smoothly and enjoys a high quality service.  We know your event is important to you and that makes it important to us.  Our customer focused team will make sure that your experience here is first class, whether youre looking for an event with 100 people or looking to utilise the entire 4,000 capacity, from your initial enquiry through to the end of your event we will put your needs at the centre of the service we provide.  Choose from our Tropicana bar area that can accommodate up to approx. 400 people, or take advantage of the large gallery room accommodating up to approx. 800 people. For those looking to organise a large scale event the outside area, enclosed by the four sea walls, can be used with a capacity of up to 3800. This area also includes a fully equipped first aid facility and toilet facilities.  If your event requires food in addition to drink then the Tropicana Bay Caf� may be able to offer you a package at competitive rates. In addition to hiring the event space we also have a basic stage, sound and lighting system at the venue. The specifications are available on request.
Tags: Theatre,  Music, exhibitions Weston

Summary: Woodspring Priory is a former Augustinian priory located near the scenic limestone promontory of Sand Point and Middle Hope. The site is a scheduled ancient monument that has significant local importance.
Description 1:
The ancient site was founded to atone for martyrdom of Thomas a Becket. The Augustinian house (of the rare Victorine rule) is surrounded by a working farm and lies by the sea. 

The museum is open most Mondays and Fridays (except Bank Holidays) between 10.30am and 3.30pm. Please contact the Booking Office before your visit, to confirm that the museum is open.

The site is owned and maintained by The Landmark Trust.
Tags: Church; Historic Structures; Heritage

Summary: An amazing water and play park that the kids will love. The ideal place to relax whilst the children have fun in the fountains, sprays and the splash pad.
Description 1:
The splash pad offers a range of fountains and sprays which are triggered by movement sensors and buttons. The port beacon, the tallest piece of equipment on the splash pad, emits a rain shower effect while others create tunnels and arches.

The wooden Stockholm Castle is just asking to be played on, as are the double cable way and the toddler area where little ones can get the musical on the xylophone or crawl through the tunnel. 

The water park also contains a sand pit, a climbing pyramid and snake swing.

The park is open all year round, with the splash pad running from April to September (weather dependent).
Description_2: The Water Adventure Play Park is located on Knightstone Road which is the sea front road next to Melrose Car Park.
Tags: Attraction; Family friendly; Play area

Summary: Annual sand sculpture event on Weston beach featuring giant sand sculptures by world class artists. There is a different theme every year which has covered everything from King Kong to Story time
Description 1: The exhibition encourages everyone to have a go at making their own sand sculptures or just to be inspired.

Summary: A diverse and wildlife rich woodland where you will find ancient trees and fascinating fungi, lichens, mosses, and wildflowers.
Description 1:
Weston Big Wood is also an area of geological interest and is a great place to just get away from it all. The best times to visit are between April and July or from September to November.

Please note that dogs must kept on a lead whilst exploring the woods.
Tags: Landscape; Nature; Outdoors and active;  Picnic area; Walking
Pet friendly: dog friendly, must be on leads

Summary: Site of Special Scientific Interest (SSSI), with an exceptionally rich flora including a number of nationally rare species, salt marsh home to wintering bird species, close to Axe
Description 1:
Wildfowl and waders can be seen on the estuary during autumn and winter, including redshank, dunlin, shelduck and black tailed godwit. 

Birds wintering on the salt marsh include skylark, rock and meadow pipit, linnet and, occasionally, twite.
Tags: Landscape; Nature; Outdoors and active;  Picnic area; Walking

Summary: A historic and archaeologically important site with far reaching views across the coast.
Description 1:

There are panoramic views over nearby Weston super Mare   the perfect spot to enjoy a quiet picnic.

Summary: Spectacular Victorian country house, gardens and arboretum managed by the National Trust
Description 1:
Tyntesfield, just a stones throw away from Bristol, was not built as a bold and extravagant statement of wealth, power or politics. Its purpose was simple; to serve as a family home. Once hidden and inaccessible, the ordinary and extraordinary lives and possessions of four generations of the Gibbs family are ready for discovery.

The garden and estate balance faded beauty and function with an abundance of nature; celebrated in ornate Gothic carvings that decorate the house. Flower filled terraces, an empty lake, woodland, champion trees and productive kitchen garden give further opportunities for exploration.
Description_2: There is also a cafe and shop on site
Tags: Attraction; Heritage; Gardens and parks; Historic Structure/site
Venue_Description: The restored sawmill is available for hire for a range of functions
Opening_Times: open all year except main bank holidays - see website
Cost Details: entry charges apply, free for National Trust members

Summary: Walk and cycle traffic free all the way from Yatton to Cheddar on the fabulous Strawberry line
Description 1:
The Cheddar Valley Line, which ran from Yatton railway station through to Cheddar and Wells, became known as the Strawberry Line because of the volume of locally grown strawberries that it carried to London markets. The Strawberry Line survived until the Beeching Axe closed it in 1963. 

The Strawberry line is a popular walking and cycling route, as well as nature reserve.
Description_2: The journey officially starts at the Strawberry Line cafe at Yatton, but can be joined at many different places, including Congresbury, Sandford (by Thatchers Cider and station) and Winscombe
Tags: Walking; Cycle;Nature; History; Outdoors and active; Cycling; Picnic area

Very steep climb, difficult wheelchair access through gate to the churchyard and along an overgrown grass path.
Tags: Walking; History; Outdoors and active; Landscape

Summary: Steep Holm is an island nature reserve in the Bristol Channel with a fascinating history. Steep Hold lies about five miles (8 km) offshore from the seaside resort of Weston super Mare
Description 1:
Steep Holm can be accessed by scheduled boat trips and is valued for being a unique nature reserve and a Site of Special Scientific Interest. The island is famed for its beautiful wild peony that flowers in May. 

Steep Holm is also home to the remains of several buildings including a 12th century Augustinian priory and Victorian fortifications. The former Barracks have been restored as a Visitor and Education/Exhibition Centre. There is a small cafe that is open seasonally.
Description_2: The six gun batteries and cannons are largely intact, and later Second World War additions including searchlight posts, gun batteries and rocket launcher sites can also be seen
Tags: Attraction; Sailing/boats; Nature; Walking; picnic area; Walking

Summary: Climb the steep hill to visit this solitary, partly ruined hilltop church, with fantastic panoramic views over the Bristol Channel, Brean Down and Weston super Mare.
Description 1: There is a very steep climb to visit this interesting landmark from Uphill.
Tags: Church; Historic Structure/site

Summary: This beautiful little church features a pirates gravestone in the churchyard, a Norman font and a stone pulpit dating from 1480.
Description 1: The church was restored in the 1820s by the Pigott family who were associated with the church for over 300 years.
Tags: Church; Historic Structure/site

Summary: The church dates back to the 15th century and features a prominent tower that was erected by society of Merchant Venturers of Bristol.
Description 1: The four stage tower is dated 1448 and the church also features a stone dole table outside where alms were given to the poor. The church is a scheduled Ancient Monument and a Grade 1 listed building.
Tags: Church; Historic Structure/site

Site_name: St Michaels Church Clapton in Gordano
Summary: St Michaels closed in 1995 but due to its architectural interest was adopted by the Churches Trust and occasional services are held throughout the year.
Description 1:
The 12th century tympanum is the oldest visible part of the church to have survived, however the majority of the building is from the 13th century.

Inside are reredos and benches, a 14th century font and a late 17th century monument.
Tags: Church; Historic Structure/site

Summary: Grade 1 listed church, churchyard cross, Conservation Area
Description 1:
Includes a Norman south doorway and octagonal font. 

There is a Jacobean altar table dating from between 1250 and 1275 with the tall figure of an unknown 13th century knight.

Summary: A unique collection of retail and farming memorabilia from the last century
Description 1:
Oakham Treasures is one of the largest privately owned museums of retail and farming history in the UK. 

Opened to the public since July 2008, it has already become an award winning major attraction, and guarantees to give you an amazing and uplifting trip down memory lane.

Whether 8 or 80, youll be fascinated by this vast and unique collection of memorabilia from the last century. There are thousands of items in the historic stores, including an impressive display of vintage tractors and farm equipment. 

The museum also has a cafe and shop

Site_name: Middle Hill Common Local Nature Reserve
Summary: A picturesque area of Common land that supports varied plants , invertebrates and butterflies, as well as being popular for walks and horse riding

Description 1:
Mendip continues to grow the number of amazing activities available, including skiing, snowboarding, watersports, rock sports, land sports and target sports.

This is where 2014 Winter Olympics medallist Jenny Jones first learned to snowboard, so even when its warm you can get your ski skills up to scratch.

The Alpine Lounge also offers locally sourced food and drink.

Why not also have a go at disc golf through the woods or become the next Bear Grylls by learning bushcraft?

Description 1:
Enjoy some relaxing fishing or visit the onsite shop selling fresh trout, smoked trout, trout gravlax. Also available are other local produce including free range eggs, cakes, preserves, local honey and apple juices.

Produce is sold at Clevedon and Portishead Farmers Markets and Nailsea Country Market.

Summary: A wonderful Medieval church with a noticeably leaning tower on the low lying north Somerset Levels.
Description 1: The church is dominated by its leaning tower with an earlier Saxo Norman nave to the south. Inside are fine oak box pews and a Jacobean oak reading desk and pulpit.
Tags: Church; Historic Structure/site

Site_name: Historic high street and modern marina in Portishead
Summary: A 3.5 long easy walk that takes in the sights and sounds of the coastal town of Portishead.
Description 1:
A paved, level walk suitable for buggies and wheelchairs. 

This walk has been extracted from North Somerset Life magazine

Summary: The Worlds Largest Dedicated Helicopter Museum featuring 80 displayed aircraft, an interactive zone and film theatre
Description 1:
The museum features regular events, including helicopter air experience flights and open cockpit days.

The collection includes a huge variety of aircraft including two of the Queens Royal Flight, the World Speed Record Holder G Lynx, a Russian Hind Gunship and the Huey Bell UH 1H.

The museum has a shop selling helicopter related memorabilia and has a cafe selling a variety of food and drink.
Tags: Attraction; Museum; History; Helicopter
Opening_Times: open all year except main bank holidays - see website

Summary: All year attraction with rides, amusements, arcades and events
Description 1:
Open every day except Christmas Day, the Pier offers world class rides and attractions and fun for all the family, from the arcade machines to thrilling rides, or a relaxing traditional afternoon tea in our exquisite Edwardian style tea rooms. 

The Pavilion building boasts function rooms, Wedding venues, state of the art conferencing facilities, entertainment and event space, all under one roof.
Description_2: The Grand Pier also boasts an action packed calendar of events for everyone to enjoy throughout the year.
Tags: Attraction; Family friendly; Beach; Restaurant; Live performance; Conferences
Venue_Description: The pier is available for hire for parties, conferences, weddings and other events

Summary: Felton Common is a 40 hectare site with a range of habitats from acidic and calcareous grassland to scrub and bracken.
Description 1:
The common lies next to the village of Felton in North Somerset with Bristol Airport located just to the west. 

The common is home to a wide variety of plants, invertebrates and birds. The site is used for both agriculture and recreation, and is particularly popular with walkers and horse riders.
Tags: Landscape; Nature; Outdoors and active;  Picnic area; Walking

Site_name: Eastwood and Battery Point Local Nature Reserve
Summary: Historic site of former batteries, woodland and pleasure grounds with Victorian broadwalk, paths and carriage drives, lake,hillfort, views over Bristol Channel, close to open air pool.
Description 1: The nature reserve is a popular place to have a picnic and enjoy the local scenery.
Tags: Landscape; Nature; Outdoors and active;  Picnic area; Walking

Summary: The Curzon is one of the oldest continually running purpose built cinemas in the world. The cinema, now owned by a community charity, continues to show the latest blockbusters
Description 1:
First opened on 20 April 1912, the Curzon is a fantastic slice of cinema history. The 270 seat cinema also has a smaller gallery room that can seat 25.

The Curzon is also home to the Oak Room, a comfortable lounge with bar where you can meet before screenings.
Tags: Cinema/film; Art and culture; Family friendly; Attraction
Venue_Description: Rooms available for events and conferences

Summary: Family farm fun with a chance to meet the animals and indoor and outdoor play facilities
Description 1:
Court Farm is simply a great family day out. 

There are many farm favourites and a range of great play facilities that can tire out even the most energetic of kids (and adults). There is a seasonal maize maze

There are interactive talks and demonstrations throughout the day to entertain all ages.

There is a café and shop on site as well as lots of free parking.
Tags: Attraction; Family friendly; Farm shop; Play area;  Outdoors and active; Restaurant
Venue_Description: Available for hire for children's parties - contact for more details
Opening_Times: open all year except main bank holidays - see website

Summary: Information Centre celebrating Isambard Kingdom Brunels world famous suspension bridge
Description 1:
Opened in 2015 the Visitor Information Centre is situated at the Leigh Woods end of the bridge. 

It contains information about the competition to design the bridge, its construction and completion and how it is maintained today. 

You can watch a DVD about the bridge, see objects from our collection (including stereoscopic images and original souvenirs) and browse our shop, where youll find  books, postcards and souvenirs.
Tags: Attraction; Museum; Historic structure/site

Summary: Award winning Grade 1 listed Victorian pier, described as the prettiest pier in England
Description 1:
Built in Victorian era, the Pier offers boat trips, fishing, events, an art gallery and shop.

The pier was also used for filming a One Direction music video in 2014. 

A new visitor centre due to be open late 2015.
Tags: Attraction; Heritage; Beach
Opening_Times: open all year except main bank holidays - see website
Cost Details: entry changes apply to pier, free access to shop

Summary: Arts and Crafts Centre featuring a diverse collection of workshops and local crafts
Description 1:
The studios and workshops are housed in the outbuildings of a 17th century Somerset long farm which was once part of the Clevedon Court Estate.

Artists in residence produce pottery, jewellery and gifts. 

There is a café on site selling home made cakes and local produce.

Follow the BROWN Craft Centre signs from junction 20 of the M5 onto the B3130.
Tags: Arts and culture; Gallery; shopping
Opening_Times: open all year except main bank holidays - see website

Summary: Outstanding 14th century manor house and 18th century terraced garden managed by the National Trust
Description 1:
Home to the lords of the manor of Clevedon for centuries, the core of the house is a remarkable survival from the medieval period. The house was purchased by Abraham Elton in 1709 and it is still the much loved family home of his descendants today.

Explore the striking display of Eltonware pottery and a fascinating collection of Nailsea glass.
Tags: Attraction; Heritage; Gardens and parks; Historic Structure/site
Opening_Times: open all year except main bank holidays - see website
Cost Details: entry charges apply, free for National Trust members

Summary: Venue hosts a variety of music, local theatre, arts and local group events.

Summary:
Clapton Moor is characteristic of the North Somerset Levels landscape. 

Networked with species rich rhynes (watery ditches), the moor is important for its breeding waders and wintering wildfowl.
Description 1:
The best time to visit Clapton Moor is between April and July or from October to February. 

Clapton Moor can be found near to the village of Clapton in Gordano, off Clevedon Lane and opposite New Farm.
Tags: Landscape; Nature; Outdoors and active;  Picnic area; Walking

Summary: Award winning glass artist Claire Hall designs and creates unique fused glass jewellery and sculpture using a variety of techniques.
Description 1: Glass casting, fusing and lampworking to name a few. Claire also runs fused glass courses and workshops in jewellery and sculptural vessels from complete beginner to bespoke advanced sessions.
Tags: Arts and culture;Studio; glass; fused glass; sculpture; jewellery; workshops

Summary:
Church House Designs in Congresbury was established 1986 and has a reputation for high quality and imaginative work. 

There is a particular emphasis on ceramics, glassware, jewellery and textiles with a wide variety of works for sale
Description 1:
Original arts and crafts sourced directly from artists studios and specialist dealers are available to buy from Church House.

Selected for quality by the Crafts Council and a member of the Independent Craft Galleries Association.
Tags: Art and culture; Gallery; shopping
Opening_Times: open all year except certain days and main bank holidays - see website

Description 1:
The theatre operates as a live events venue, programming local and regional theatre, music and dance. The venue is also regularly hired by the RAFA concert band and Weston College Performing Arts department. 

The Blakehay Theatre has a 207 seat theatre and a cafe. There is full disabled access either front of house or backstage.

Summary: Artists studios and award winning Ethicurean Restaurant
Description 1:
Barley Wood Walled Garden is a carefully restored Victorian kitchen garden built for Henry Herbert Wills and his family in 1901. The Walled Garden has five resident artists whose Studios are open to the public. 

The garden grows a huge array of vegetables some of which are heritage and heirloom varieties. 

The garden has excellent examples of espaliers and cordon fruit trees
Description_2: Paintings, pottery, garden ceramics, kiln formed glass and enamel. Courses and special events take place during the year. Please note that the opening times vary for each studio, and are not the same as the cafe opening times.
Tags: Food and Drink; Arts and Crafts; Restaurant; Local produce

Summary: Since construction in the 1970s, Backwell lake has become an important site for wildfowl and dragonflies and also as a foraging area for bats.
Description 1:
Backwell Lake was constructed in the mid 1970s as a balancing pond and is owned by Wessex Water. 

The site consists of an area of open water with a small island and some marginal vegetation.
Tags: Landscape; Nature; Outdoors and active; Picnic area; Walking

Summary: A long distance 85 mile circular route around Bristol taking in wooded hillsides, section of Somerset levels, coast and dramatic Avon Gorge. Some sections traffic free but route mainly on country road
Description 1:
This varied route includes wooded hillsides, a section of the Somerset levels and beautiful coastline. 

The cycleway is signed as Sustrans National Route 410.
Tags: Cycling; Nature; Outdoors and active

Site_name: Ashton Court country park and mansion
Summary: Country park and mansion with 850 acres of woodland and grassland and many activities
Description 1:
Ashton Court is home to cafes, woodland garden, picnic area, cycle trail and natural play area. 

Admission is free, although there is a charge for admission to some events which take place on the estate. 

Access may be restricted on some major event days.
Description_2: Ashton Court is the third most visited country park in England
Tags: Attraction; Heritage; Gardens and parks; Historic Structure/site
